dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? It says here, like, the S&P 500 is up 4.5% since the George Floyd protests started?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? It says here, like, the S&P five hundred is up four point five percent since the George Floyd protests started?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Right now, the S&P 500 is up 4.5% since protests over the death of George Floyd began on May 26.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, um, that's what the article says. It's, uh, been a pretty consistent pattern historically, actually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, um, that's what the article says. It's, uh, been a pretty consistent pattern historically, actually.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The disconnect between whats taking place on streets across America and the American stock market has stumped many investors but its not a new phenomenon. Heres how similar periods of civil unrest have played out in the market throughout history.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Consistent? You're telling me that, like, while the country's literally on fire, the stock market's just... shrugging its shoulders?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Consistent? You're telling me that, like, while the country's literally on fire, the stock market's just... shrugging its shoulders?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, the article points to things like the 1963 Kennedy assassination, the S&P still added almost 22% then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, uh, the article points to things like the nineteen sixty three Kennedy assassination, the S&P still added almost twenty two percent then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1963, when President Kennedy was assassinated, the S&P added nearly 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Kennedy was assassinated and the market went up? Come on, that's just... that's messed up. Like, defense spending, really? That's the reason?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kennedy was assassinated and the market went up? Come on, that's just... that's messed up. Like, defense spending, really? That's the reason?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, that's what, uh, the analysis suggests. And, you know, 1968, MLK assassinated, S&P still gained 8%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, that's what, uh, the analysis suggests. And, you know, nineteen sixty eight, M L K assassinated, S&P still gained eight percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1968, the year Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, the S&P gained 8%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what, like, tragedy just... fuels the economy? This is insane. Are investors just completely devoid of, like, human feeling?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what, like, tragedy just... fuels the economy? This is insane. Are investors just completely devoid of, like, human feeling?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The article quotes Jim Cramer, uh, saying "the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The article quotes Jim Cramer, uh, saying the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of the day, the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money, CNBCs Jim Cramer said this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No conscience? Yeah, no kidding. That's, uh, a pretty grim assessment. What about the Iraq War protests in 2003? The S&P jumped 26% then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No conscience? Yeah, no kidding. That's, uh, a pretty grim assessment. What about the Iraq War protests in two thousand three? The S&P jumped twenty six percent then?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2003, after protests erupted around the world over the Iraq War, the S&P jumped an eye watering 26%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, um, investors are often looking beyond current events. They're, uh, focusing on what's next, like, the promise of recovery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, um, investors are often looking beyond current events. They're, uh, focusing on what's next, like, the promise of recovery.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors are continuing to ignore the three Pspandemic, protests and politicsand are instead focused on what increasingly is being interpreted as a quicker and better than expected recovery in the economy, David Donabedian, chief investment officer at CIBC Private Wealth Management, told the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But there was, like, a 20% unemployment rate predicted for May. And, uh, damage to the economy for months, maybe years, it says here. That's not "next."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But there was, like, a twenty percent unemployment rate predicted for May. And, uh, damage to the economy for months, maybe years, it says here. That's not next.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: experts looked ahead to a dismal May unemployment rate on the order of 20%... That damage has the potential to weigh on earnings and profits for months, if not years, and a soaring unemployment rate will only worsen the situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The article does say investors are ignoring, uh, the "three Ps"—pandemic, protests, politics—and, uh, are focused on a quicker recovery. And the Fed's interventions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The article does say investors are ignoring, uh, the three Ps-pandemic, protests, politics-and, uh, are focused on a quicker recovery. And the Fed's interventions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors are continuing to ignore the three Pspandemic, protests and politicsand are instead focused on what increasingly is being interpreted as a quicker and better than expected recovery in the economy... buoyed by the prospects of a quick recovery and the effectiveness of the Feds unprecedented interventions in the market...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ignoring them? That's, uh, that's just delusional, isn't it? Like, this all sounds like, you know, whistling past the graveyard.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ignoring them? That's, uh, that's just delusional, isn't it? Like, this all sounds like, you know, whistling past the graveyard.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Todd Lowenstein from HighMark Capital Management, uh, he says markets will price in a recovery well before the economic data bottoms. The market tends to be ahead of the actual data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Todd Lowenstein from HighMark Capital Management, uh, he says markets will price in a recovery well before the economic data bottoms. The market tends to be ahead of the actual data.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Markets will price in a recovery well before the economic data bottoms, says Todd Lowenstein, chief equity strategist at HighMark Capital Management. The market tends to be ahead of the actual data itself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, the S&P is soaring, but the worst is yet to come? That just, uh, doesn't make any sense. It's totally disconnected. It feels like, um, it's just ignoring reality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, the S&P is soaring, but the worst is yet to come? That just, uh, doesn't make any sense. It's totally disconnected. It feels like, um, it's just ignoring reality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That means that the worst could be yet to come, even though the S&P seems poised to soar.
